data.body:
The new schema for job ids consists on a single hash, generated using the `uuid` module. The former schema was: `arthur-<task_id>-hash`.

* The `arthur-` prefix was set in the past to identify jobs coming from different sources (not from `arthur`).

By removing this prefix the job ids are now simpler, as the origin of the job could be included as meta-data instead of a part of the job id.
    
* The `task_id` parameter comes from the task triggering the job.

By removing this section, we are avoiding future problems as this field could contain white-spaces or other unusual characters.

* Although it was not strictly necessary to modify the corresponding tests, I have updated the made-up job names by removing the `arthur-` prefix and the `task_id` value.

This PR is related with issue #83 .
data.title: [scheduler] Remove 'arthur' prefix from job ids schema

data.body: This PR addresses https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-kingarthur/issues/85. In a nutshell, the params `--no-daemon` and `--log-path` are set as mutually exclusive. If Arthurd is run as daemon, the log messages are set to `log-path` (by default `os.path.expanduser('~/.arthur/logs/')`), otherwise the log messages are sent to `stderr`.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -199,22 +198,26 @@ def create_common_arguments_parser(defaults):
                         help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
     parser.add_argument('--es-index', dest='es_index',
                         help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
-    parser.add_argument('--log-path', dest='log_path',
-                        default=os.path.expanduser('~/.arthur/logs/'),
-                        help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
     parser.add_argument('--archive-path', dest='archive_path',
                         default=os.path.expanduser(ARCHIVES_DEFAULT_PATH),
                         help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
     parser.add_argument('--no-archive', dest='no_archive',
                         action='store_true',
                         help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
-    parser.add_argument('--no-daemon', dest='no_daemon',
-                        action='store_true',
-                        help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
     parser.add_argument('--pubsub-channel', dest='pubsub_channel',
                         default=CH_PUBSUB,
                         help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
 
+    group_log = parser.add_argument_group('Log handling')
+    exclusive_log = group_log.add_mutually_exclusive_group()
+
+    exclusive_log.add_argument('--log-path', dest='log_path',
+                               default=os.path.expanduser('~/.arthur/logs/'),
+                               help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
+    exclusive_log.add_argument('--no-daemon', dest='no_daemon',
+                               action='store_true',
+                               help=argparse.SUPPRESS)
+
review_comments_data.body:
Taking into account @sanacl comment, the behaviour is right but this part is misleading. The option `--no-daemon` is not related to the logs, so it shouldn't be under that group. Specially because if you run `arthurd -h` that option will be under `Log handling` section.

I think we need a better solution for this, probably just ignoring `--log-path` when `--no-daemon` is set. You can include a comment like `no effect when running in the foreground` in the help section.

data.title: [bin] Send arthur messages to stderr if --no-daemon is on

data.body:
This PR adds a new endpoint to the CherryPy server that will return the job data using the resource /job/<job_id>. It includes also the corresponding test.


Related to #79

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:

         return task_dict
+
+    @cherrypy.expose
+    @cherrypy.tools.json_out(handler=json_encoder)
+    def job(self, job_id):
+        """Get info about a task"""
review_comments_data.body: This should be reworded as `Get info about a job`

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -184,3 +184,41 @@ def task(self, task_id):
         logger.debug("Task %s data generated", task_id)
 
         return task_dict
+

+    @cherrypy.tools.json_out(handler=json_encoder)
+    def job(self, job_id):
+        """Get info about a task"""
+
+        logger.debug("API 'task' method called for job %s", job_id)

review_comments_data.body:
This can be compressed into:
```
job_result = result.to_dict() if isinstance(result, JobResult) else None
```

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:

review_comments_data.body:
This can be compressed into:

```

```

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -292,6 +293,88 @@ def test_task(self, mock_utcnow):
 
             self.assertEqual(job_result, expected_job_result)
 
+    @unittest.mock.patch('arthur.tasks.datetime_utcnow')

review_comments_data.body: Change it for `Check whether job data is retrieved`.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -292,6 +293,88 @@ def test_task(self, mock_utcnow):
 
             self.assertEqual(job_result, expected_job_result)

+    def test_job(self, mock_utcnow):

data.body:
In order to save the logs of each job, this commit adds the
functionality of storing them in the "meta" field of the job, that
will be saved in Redis.

This commit includes a new log handler for the arthur, perceval
and rq.worker loggers. These loggers have information about the
job execution, so the logs are filtered by the job id before
save them.

---

Related to #72

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -53,6 +54,75 @@ def test_publish_job_events_channel_override(self):
 
         self._publish_job_events('test_channel', pubsub_override=True)
 
+    def test_job_log_handler_init(self):
+        """Tests whether the handler has initialized well"""
+
+        job_a = rq.job.Job()
+        meta_handler = JobLogHandler(job_a)
+        self.assertEqual(meta_handler.job, job_a)
+        self.assertEqual(len(meta_handler.job.meta['log']), 0)
review_comments_data.body: I think is better to test that `log` stores an empty list with `self.assertListEqual(meta_handler.job.meta['log'], [])`.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -53,6 +54,75 @@ def test_publish_job_events_channel_override(self):
 
         self._publish_job_events('test_channel', pubsub_override=True)
 
+    def test_job_log_handler_init(self):
+        """Tests whether the handler has initialized well"""
+
+        job_a = rq.job.Job()
+        meta_handler = JobLogHandler(job_a)
+        self.assertEqual(meta_handler.job, job_a)
+        self.assertEqual(len(meta_handler.job.meta['log']), 0)
+
+    def test_job_log_handler_emit(self):
+        """Tests whether the handler has initialized well"""
+
+        job_a = rq.job.Job()
+
+        # Create handler
+        meta_handler = JobLogHandler(job_a)
+
+        # Get logger of this current context and add set level to INFO in order to save info and upper
+        logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
+        logger.addHandler(meta_handler)
+        logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
+
+        # Write in the logger
+        logger.error("Error log to the handler")
+        logger.warning("Warning log to the handler")
+        logger.info("Info log to the handler")
+
+        # Check if the logs are saved in the job meta field
+        self.assertEqual(len(job_a.meta['log']), 3)
+        self.assertEqual(sorted(list(job_a.meta['log'][0].keys())), ['created', 'level', 'module', 'msg'])
+        self.assertRegex(job_a.meta['log'][0]['msg'], 'Error')
+        self.assertRegex(job_a.meta['log'][-1]['msg'], 'Info')
review_comments_data.body: This should be moved to a different test case. Create a class `TestJobLogHandler` and add these tests there.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -53,6 +54,75 @@ def test_publish_job_events_channel_override(self):
 
         self._publish_job_events('test_channel', pubsub_override=True)
 
+    def test_job_log_handler_init(self):
+        """Tests whether the handler has initialized well"""
+
+        job_a = rq.job.Job()
+        meta_handler = JobLogHandler(job_a)
+        self.assertEqual(meta_handler.job, job_a)
+        self.assertEqual(len(meta_handler.job.meta['log']), 0)
+
+    def test_job_log_handler_emit(self):
+        """Tests whether the handler has initialized well"""
review_comments_data.body: This comment is wrong.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -28,10 +28,28 @@
 from .common import CH_PUBSUB
 from .events import JobEventType, JobEvent
 
-
+JOB_LOGGERS = ['arthur', 'perceval', 'rq']
 logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
 
 
+class JobLogHandler(logging.StreamHandler):
+    def __init__(self, job):
review_comments_data.body: Can you add some documentation to this class?

data.body:
In order to fix the bug described in #98, this PR adds the next functionality:

- In the scheduler, the job_number field now is saved in the metadata of the job.
- The server picks the job_number from the metadata instead of the result.

data.body:
This series of commits allow to re-schedule tasks that failed at some point. When a failed tasks is re-schedule some of its properties are reset. Specifically, the age of the task and the number of failures are reset to 0.

The commits include also the API REST call `reschedule` that allow to run again a set of tasks.

This commit fulfills the requirements of issue #76.
data.title: Reschedule failed tasks

reviews_data.body: Great work! Although, there are some minor changes required before accepting this patch.

Besides the specific comments, there are problems with the locks. If there's an exception with the connection in redis the system will stuck because locks will never be released.
It is necessary to add try...catch...finally blocks or a similar solution to those places in `TaskRegistry` where the read-write block is used.

data.body:
This PR addresses https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-kingarthur/issues/88. In a nutshell, tasks are now saved in redis. This implies some changes in the scheduler, arthur and task registry.

New tests have been provided, old ones have been updated accordingly.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,14 +180,14 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
 
-        if task_id in self._tasks:
+        if task_id in [k.decode("utf-8") for k in self.conn.keys()]:
review_comments_data.body: Shouldn't be better to use [EXISTS](https://redis.io/commands/exists) or [GET](https://redis.io/commands/get) **Redis** methods to check if a task is stored?

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,6 +241,32 @@ def get(self, task_id):
 
         return task
 
+    def update(self, task_id, task):
+        """Update a task in the registry.
+
+        Update a task store in the registry using its task identifier. When
review_comments_data.body: A type in `store`. It should be `stored`.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,6 +241,32 @@ def get(self, task_id):
 
         return task
 
+    def update(self, task_id, task):
+        """Update a task in the registry.
+
+        Update a task store in the registry using its task identifier. When
+        the task does not exist, a `NotFoundError` exception will be
+        raised.
+
+        :param task_id: task identifier
+        :param task: task object
+
+        :returns: a task object
+
+        :raises NotFoundError: raised when the requested task is not
+            found on the registry
+        """
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
review_comments_data.body: This lock usage is wrong. It should be `writer_acquire`. We'll have race conditions if we use `reader_acquire`.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -49,7 +49,7 @@ def __init__(self, conn, base_archive_path=None, async_mode=True, pubsub_channel
         rq.push_connection(self.conn)
 
         self.archive_path = base_archive_path
-        self._tasks = TaskRegistry()
+        self._tasks = TaskRegistry(self.conn)
review_comments_data.body: This can be merged with the first commit.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -327,10 +350,10 @@ def test_task_not_rescheduled_age_limit(self):
         handler = CompletedJobHandler(self.task_scheduler)
 
         scheduler_opts = SchedulingTaskConfig(delay=0, max_retries=0, max_age=3)
-        task = self.registry.add('mytask', 'git', 'commit', {},
-                                 scheduling_cfg=scheduler_opts)
+        task = self.task_scheduler.registry.add('mytask', 'git', 'commit', {}, scheduling_cfg=scheduler_opts)
review_comments_data.body:
Would you mind to reduce the size of this line? Following the style of the original line the format would be:

```
task = self.task_scheduler.registry.add('mytask', 'git', 'commit', {},
                                        scheduling_cfg=scheduler_opts)
```

I think this is easier to read and to review.

There are other lines like these you changed on this commit too.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,14 +180,14 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
 
-        if task_id in self._tasks:
+        if task_id in [k.decode("utf-8") for k in self.conn.keys()]:
             self._rwlock.writer_release()
             raise AlreadyExistsError(element=str(task_id))
 
         task = Task(task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
                     archiving_cfg=archiving_cfg,
                     scheduling_cfg=scheduling_cfg)
-        self._tasks[task_id] = task
+        self.conn.set(task_id, pickle.dumps(task))
review_comments_data.body: I'm not a big fun of this solution but it might work for now.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,14 +180,14 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
 
-        if task_id in self._tasks:
+        if task_id in [k.decode("utf-8") for k in self.conn.keys()]:
             self._rwlock.writer_release()
             raise AlreadyExistsError(element=str(task_id))
 
         task = Task(task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
                     archiving_cfg=archiving_cfg,
                     scheduling_cfg=scheduling_cfg)
-        self._tasks[task_id] = task
+        self.conn.set(task_id, pickle.dumps(task))
review_comments_data.body:
In the case `self.conn.set` fails due to any kind of error (for example, connection errors), this will lock the `rwlock` object forever because it is never released. We should work with `try...except..finally` blocks to fix this problem.

It should be added in all the operations inside the registry.

This wasn't a problem before because tasks were stored in memory.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,6 +241,32 @@ def get(self, task_id):
 
         return task
 
+    def update(self, task_id, task):
+        """Update a task in the registry.
+
+        Update a task store in the registry using its task identifier. When
+        the task does not exist, a `NotFoundError` exception will be
+        raised.
+
+        :param task_id: task identifier
+        :param task: task object
+
+        :returns: a task object
+
+        :raises NotFoundError: raised when the requested task is not
+            found on the registry
+        """
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+
+        if task_id not in [k.decode("utf-8") for k in self.conn.keys()]:
+            self._rwlock.reader_release()
+            raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
+
+        self.conn.set(task_id, pickle.dumps(task))
review_comments_data.body: If this raises an exception, other processes might get stuck because the lock is never released.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,7 @@ def schedule_task(self, task_id, delay=0):
 
         self._tasks_events[task_id] = event
         task.status = TaskStatus.SCHEDULED
+        self.registry.update(task_id, task)
review_comments_data.body: Calls to `update` or any other method related to `registry` might cause the code crash. We have to be sure we can handle these errors propertly.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -204,13 +208,16 @@ def remove(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the given task identifier
             is not found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-            del self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.writer_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
+        self.conn.expire(task_id, -1)
review_comments_data.body: I think we should keep the usage of `DEL` because expire would to the same but slower.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -228,26 +235,67 @@ def get(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the requested task is not
             found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
-            task = self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        task_dump = self.conn.get(task_id)
+        task = pickle.loads(task_dump)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
review_comments_data.body: Here there's a race condition. A writer can remove the data between the two blocks which will make you to have an empty task object.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -204,13 +208,16 @@ def remove(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the given task identifier
             is not found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-            del self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.writer_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
+        self.conn.expire(task_id, -1)
+        self._rwlock.writer_release()
review_comments_data.body:
This is not a race condition because the way redis works which is that if the key doesn't exist it would do nothing. The problem is you need to know exactly the behaviour of `expire`.

I think it's better to follow a defensive programming, which will be to include everything under a writer block.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -204,13 +208,16 @@ def remove(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the given task identifier
             is not found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-            del self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.writer_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
+        self.conn.expire(task_id, -1)
+        self._rwlock.writer_release()
review_comments_data.body: The same happens in other parts of the code.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -228,26 +235,67 @@ def get(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the requested task is not
             found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
-            task = self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        task_dump = self.conn.get(task_id)
+        task = pickle.loads(task_dump)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
 
         return task
 
+    def update(self, task_id, task):
+        """Update a task in the registry.
+
+        Update a task stored in the registry using its task identifier. When
+        the task does not exist, a `NotFoundError` exception will be
+        raised.
+
+        :param task_id: task identifier
+        :param task: task object
+
+        :returns: a task object
+        """
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
+            logger.warning("Task %s not found, adding it", str(task_id))
+
+        self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
+        self.conn.set(task_id, pickle.dumps(task))
+        self._rwlock.writer_release()
+
+        logger.debug("Task %s updated", str(task_id))
+
     @property
     def tasks(self):
         """Get the list of tasks"""
 
         self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
-        tl = [v for v in self._tasks.values()]
-        tl.sort(key=lambda x: x.task_id)
+        tasks = []
+        keys = []
+
+        total, found = self.conn.scan()
+        keys.extend([f.decode("utf-8") for f in found])
+        while total != 0:
+            total, found = self.conn.scan(cursor=total)
review_comments_data.body:
I realized this will return all the objects stored in the database. In this case, jobs, messages, etc. I think tasks should have an internal prefix. RQ uses a prefix, so probably we can use the same. For example, when you try to access a job with a hash, you use that hash but internally RQ looks for keys with the value `rq:Job:<hash>` or something similar.

We will need a test for this case too, where there's something stored in the database that is not a task and this method returns only the tasks.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -204,13 +208,16 @@ def remove(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the given task identifier
             is not found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-            del self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.writer_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
+        self.conn.expire(task_id, -1)
review_comments_data.body: `DEL` is reported as dangerous command: https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-and-secure-redis-on-debian-10#step-5-%E2%80%94-renaming-dangerous-commands

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -204,13 +208,16 @@ def remove(self, task_id):
         :raises NotFoundError: raised when the given task identifier
             is not found on the registry
         """
-        try:
-            self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-            del self._tasks[task_id]
-        except KeyError:
+        self._rwlock.reader_acquire()
+        found = self.conn.exists(task_id)
+        self._rwlock.reader_release()
+
+        if not found:
             raise NotFoundError(element=str(task_id))
-        finally:
-            self._rwlock.writer_release()
+
+        self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
+        self.conn.expire(task_id, -1)
review_comments_data.body:
Yeah I read it  but the rationale is it is dangerous because someone can delete keys. If you don't abuse of that is fine. Morover, I don't see the point of using `expire` when `rq` uses `delete` too.

https://github.com/rq/rq/blob/master/rq/job.py#L594

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,6 +45,9 @@
 logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
 
 
+TASK_PREFIX = 'arthur-task-'
review_comments_data.body:
I think we should use the same schema RQ uses. See it in https://github.com/rq/rq/blob/master/rq/job.py#L84.
In this case, this would be `arthur:task:`.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -149,11 +155,18 @@ class TaskRegistry:
     identifier.
 
     The registry ensures mutual exclusion among threads using a
-    reading-writting lock (`RWLock` on `utils` module).
+    reading-writing lock (`RWLock` on `utils` module).
+
+    :param conn: connection Object to Redis
     """
-    def __init__(self):
+    def __init__(self, conn):
+        self.conn = conn
         self._rwlock = RWLock()
-        self._tasks = {}
+
+    @staticmethod
+    def _task_key(task_id):
+
review_comments_data.body: You can remove this blank line.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -172,48 +185,59 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
 
         :returns: the new task added to the registry
 
-        :raises AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
-            exists on the registry
+        :raises: AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
review_comments_data.body: After `raises` don't add a colon (`:`) character.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -172,48 +185,59 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
 
         :returns: the new task added to the registry
 
-        :raises AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
-            exists on the registry
+        :raises: AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
+            already exists in the registry
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-
-        if task_id in self._tasks:
+        try:
+            task_key = self._task_key(task_id)
+            found = self.conn.exists(task_key)
+
+            if found:
+                self._rwlock.writer_release()
review_comments_data.body: This call is not needed because we have the same call under the `finally` block. This can also be removed from the other methods where you do the same.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -172,48 +185,59 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
 
         :returns: the new task added to the registry
 
-        :raises AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
-            exists on the registry
+        :raises: AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
+            already exists in the registry
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-
-        if task_id in self._tasks:
+        try:
+            task_key = self._task_key(task_id)
+            found = self.conn.exists(task_key)
+
+            if found:
+                self._rwlock.writer_release()
+                raise AlreadyExistsError(element=str(task_id))
+
+            task = Task(task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
+                        archiving_cfg=archiving_cfg,
+                        scheduling_cfg=scheduling_cfg)
+            self.conn.set(task_key, pickle.dumps(task))
+
+            logger.debug("Task %s added to the registry", str(task_id))
+            return task
+        except RedisError as e:
+            logger.error("Task %s not added: %s", str(task_id), str(e))
review_comments_data.body: In the case, this fails we are not managing in any way in the rest of the code this failure. It happens the same with the rest of calls to the registry. What should be the best method? We can either raise a custom exception catch it in where the module calls this or return `False`, `None`, and manage those values too.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -172,48 +185,59 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
 
         :returns: the new task added to the registry
 
-        :raises AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
-            exists on the registry
+        :raises: AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
+            already exists in the registry
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-
-        if task_id in self._tasks:

+            task_key = self._task_key(task_id)
+            found = self.conn.exists(task_key)
+
+            if found:
+                self._rwlock.writer_release()

+
+            task = Task(task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
+                        archiving_cfg=archiving_cfg,
+                        scheduling_cfg=scheduling_cfg)
+            self.conn.set(task_key, pickle.dumps(task))
+
+            logger.debug("Task %s added to the registry", str(task_id))
+            return task
+        except RedisError as e:
+            logger.error("Task %s not added: %s", str(task_id), str(e))
review_comments_data.body: I'm fine with any solution. If you decide to go for the custom exception, propose its name.

review_comments_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -172,48 +185,59 @@ def add(self, task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
 
         :returns: the new task added to the registry
 
-        :raises AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
-            exists on the registry
+        :raises: AlreadyExistsError: raised when the given task identifier
+            already exists in the registry
         """
         self._rwlock.writer_acquire()
-
-        if task_id in self._tasks:
+        try:
+            task_key = self._task_key(task_id)
+            found = self.conn.exists(task_key)
+
+            if found:
+                self._rwlock.writer_release()
+                raise AlreadyExistsError(element=str(task_id))
+
+            task = Task(task_id, backend, category, backend_args,
+                        archiving_cfg=archiving_cfg,
+                        scheduling_cfg=scheduling_cfg)
+            self.conn.set(task_key, pickle.dumps(task))
+
+            logger.debug("Task %s added to the registry", str(task_id))
+            return task
+        except RedisError as e:
+            logger.error("Task %s not added: %s", str(task_id), str(e))
review_comments_data.body: Let's go with the custom exception. `TaskRegistryException` might work.

data.title: store tasks using redis

repo.description: King Arthur commands his loyal knight Perceval on the quest to retrieve data from software repositories.
